results.title: Extremities
results.creator_credit: Atlantic Entertainment, Thomas Coleman, George W. Perkins, Michael Rosenblatt, Scott Rosenfelt, Burt Sugarman and Robert Young
results.brief_description: Attacked but unharmed by a masked assailant, Marjorie (Farrah Fawcett) lives in mortal fear that the unidentified man will strike again - especially since he knows where she lives. Her attacker (James Russo) breaks into her home again and subjects her to a night of terror and sexual humiliation, however Marjorie manages to turn the tables on him, knocking him unconscious and rendering him helpless. She is then faced with a major moral dilemma, should she turn him in to the police or should she mete out her own punishment, and if so, what would be a fitting form? This is a film about random violence and the focus of the movie is on the moral dilemma Marjorie faces, the depiction of graphic violence in the film is shocking at times, but a standout, harrowing performance by Farrah Fawcett makes it compulsive viewing.

results.title: Extreme prejudice
results.creator_credit: Carolco Pictures, Tri-Star Pictures, Buzz Feitshans and Walter Hill
results.brief_description: Director Walter Hill helms this macho neo-Western with aplomb, providing a plethora of violence and mayhem, in the style of Sam Peckinpah (Hill worked as a screenwriter on several Peckinpah films). Nick Nolte plays Jack Benteen, a Texas Ranger with an incendiary attitude (that apes Dirty Harry), driven by the lawlessness and brutality that has invaded his hometown since the drug trade has escalated there. Heading a key operation is former friend, Cash Bailey; Cash and Benteen are in love with the same sexy Mexican woman, currently Benteen’s girlfriend, which incenses their conflict. Benteen’s success in disarming his former friend is limited and he is countered by a crack team of mercenaries, all ex-army and officially dead or missing, who have been engaged to eliminate Cash and his merciless crew. The bloodshed in this film is quite relentless, lots of bullet-riddled bodies and big guns, interspersed with numerous high tech crimes. Hill tries to keep the central conflict interesting but the variety of sub-plots and the many scenes of testosterone fuelled vicious encounters, muddies the narrative focus.

results.title: Exodus
results.brief_description: As the famous theme plays under the opening credits, the tone is set for this powerful, historical drama. Based upon Leon Uris’ international bestseller, “Exodus” chronicles the plight of post-war Jews in their fight to establish a homeland in Israel. Paul Newman gives a compelling performance as a resistance fighter who challenges British authority and brings Jewish refugees into Palestine. Eva Marie Saint is the compassionate American nurse who joins the cause. Their relationship grows as the events of the independence movement swirl around them, and when Sal Mineo, a young Auschwitz survivor, joins in terrorist acts against the British, the screen explodes with tension-filled excitement. Filmed on location in Cyprus and Palestine, this epic drama received several Academy Award nominations and won for Best Score. Also stars Ralph Richardson, John Derek, Peter Lawford and Lee J. Cobb.

results.title: eXistenZ = Existenz [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Alliance Atlantis, Serendipity Point Films, Robert Lantos, Andras Hamori and David Cronenberg
results.brief_description: Inspired by a 1995 interview with writer Salman Rushdie, “Existenz” sees Cronenberg apply his perverse and rigorous intellect to a future world in which video game technology and genetic engineering have combined. Allegra Geller (Jennifer Jason Leigh) is a whiz-bang game creator who is the target of an assassination attempt. Geller’s creations simulate the exact sensory and physiological experiences of human reality and she becomes a target of a fundamentalist “realist” cult who object to her experimentation with consciousness. Jude Law plays a young man hired to protect Geller and she introduces him to the labyrinthe, exotic and sometimes terrifying world of virtual reality. Unlike much science-fiction which explores the virtual future, Cronenberg is not as much interested in the possibilities of special effects as he is with the question of what effect do experimentations with computers, designer drugs and genetics have with our ability to understand consciousness and human will. In the near future of “Existenz”, it is not only the human sense of reality that is altered, but our very physical selves. The film itself is a fast paced, ever-changing rollercoaster ride which takes us through myriad permutations of setting and character that in itself unfolds like a video game. As always in Cronenberg’s films, the production design, sound and cinematography is excellent. “Existenz” is a rarity: a film as visceral as it is cerebral.

results.title: Evil angels
results.brief_description: No body. No motive. No weapon. The facts in the Australian murder trial of Lindy and Michael Chamberlain didn’t add up. But strangely, other things did. Things like bigotry against the couple’s religion. Scattershot forensic evidence was accepted as fact. And a nationwide hysteria that was the 1980s equivalent of the Salem witchhunt. Much of “Evil Angels” has the bizarre ring of the tabloid headlines. The wholesale abandonment of reason and justice seems too preposterous to be possible in a free and modern country. Believe it. It’s documented in John Bryson’s book “Evil Angels”. Stars Meryl Streep and Sam Neill.

results.title: Everyone says I love you
results.creator_credit: Buena Vista Pictures, Magnolia Productions, Miramax Films, Sweetland Films BV, Charles H. Joffe, Jack Rollins, Robert Greenhut and Woody Allen
results.brief_description: This story of a very well off family living in New York takes the audience on a journey through their daily lives, highlighting the high and lows. The basic family set-up involves the two parents, Bob (Alan Alda) and Steffi (Goldie Hawn), four daughters, a son, a grandfather, and Joe (Woody Allen) - Steffi’s ex-husband. Joe is still very much a part of the family and regularly visits from his home in Paris. Joe seems to have had an endless array of failed relationships, and continuously pines for his ex-lovers. Meanwhile, the eldest daughter, Skylar (Drew Barrymore) is deeply in love with Holden (Edward Norton). Music and an ensemble performance drive the intertwined love stories, which revolve around the members of an extended blended family. The story structure is almost a dance of life that continuously circles around in a cycle of love found, lost, and then found again. The disparate story elements are unified by the use of the narrator DJ (Natasha Lyonne), who is the college-age daughter of Steffi by a previous marriage to Joe. Like almost everyone else in the film, DJ is a romantic at heart who seems to be always falling in and out of love. In addition to narrating, she acts as cupid in helping Joe meet Von (Julia Roberts), a woman he has fallen in love with at first sight. All the principal actors are given at least one song, and with the exception of Drew Barrymore, do their own singing rather than have the voice of a professional singer dubbed in.

results.title: Europa Europa
results.creator_credit: Les Films du Losange, Filmkunst, Arthur Brauner and Agnieszka Holland
results.brief_description: A movie that proves that fact is far more bizarre than fiction. Based on the autobiography of Solomon Perel, “Europa Europa” follows the extraordinary adventures of a Jewish boy becomes one of the prize pupils in the Hitler Youth. Young Solomon’s attempts to evade the Nazi slaughter of the Jews is a tragi-comedy of epic porportions. While the war escalates in horror and intensity, Solomon relies on his good looks and sharp wits to survive. From Communist training camp to the elite Nazi school in Berlin, Solomon’s journey takes him across Germany, Poland and Eastern Europe. “Europa Europa” is such an exhilerating movie to watch - fast, colourful, exciting - it is only on reflection that the full resonance of Solomon’s story has its effect. His chameleon changes of self in order to survive undermine both radical and humanist notions of the “hero” and the film asks unsettling and difficult questions about complicity and collaboration in violence. This film is alive: one moment we are laughing out loud at Solomon’s attempts to hide his penis from view (and its telling lack of foreskin) and in the next moment we confront the stark inhuman obscenity of the Warsaw Ghetto. A rivetting, important, complex film.

results.title: Eternal sunshine of the spotless mind
results.creator_credit: Focus Features, Steve Golin, Anthony Bregman and Michel Gondry
results.brief_description: Joel (Jim Carrey) and Clementine’s (Kate Winslet) relationship isn’t going too well so she engages a psychiatrist to employ a process whereby Joel and the relationship is erased from her memory. On finding out about the procedure Joel thinks he’ll do the same but the couple actually re-discover more about the start of their relationship and what brought them together in the first place. In a quirky look at relationships, break-ups and a kind of love-conquers-all mystique this romantic/black comedy stems from the same key team that put together “Human Nature” - director Michel Gondry and writer Charlie Kaufman. Cast includes Kirsten Dunst, Mark Ruffalo, Elijah Wood, Tom Wilkinson.

results.title: Escape to Witch Mountain
results.creator_credit: Walt Disney Productions, Jerome Courtland and John Hough
results.brief_description: Two orphans develop telekinetic powers and escape from exploitative adults with the aid of a grieving widow. They retreat to Witch Mountain, discovering their powers, which include predicting the future, levitating objects and mastery over animals. This extremely popular family oriented children’s film features Eddie Albert, Ray Milland, and Donald Pleasence, with Kim Richards and Ike Eisenmann, playing the imperilled children.

results.title: Escape from New York
results.creator_credit: AVCO Embassy Pictures, Debra Hill, Larry Franco and John Carpenter
results.brief_description: John Carpenter’s “Escape from New York” images the entire metropolis as a maximum security prison, where dangerous criminals and political dissidents are sent to serve out life sentences with no chance of parole. Carpenter’s dystopic vision populates the crumbling city with subway dwelling nomads and marauding gangs that rule the streets with chaos and destruction. When the President of the United States (Donald Pleasence) crashes his plane into the prison area, condemned criminal and one time war hero Snake Plissken (played with laconic glee by Kurt Russell), is sent in to rescue him from the highly dangerous fortress. Carpenter’s cult hit is a subversive and satirical take on a New York which was at the time (it was made in 1982), riddled with crime and corruption. The film also takes swipes at right wing paranoia by offering an alarming vision of how the average American would really like to solve escalating crime. Cast includes Isaac Hayes, Harry Dean Stanton, Ernest Borgnine, Lee Van Cleef and Adrienne Barbeau.
results.creator_credit_for_label: AVCO Embassy Pictures, Debra Hill, Larry Franco and John Carpenter
results.description: John Carpenter’s “Escape from New York” images the entire metropolis as a maximum security prison, where dangerous criminals and political dissidents are sent to serve out life sentences with no chance of parole. Carpenter’s dystopic vision populates the crumbling city with subway dwelling nomads and marauding gangs that rule the streets with chaos and destruction. When the President of the United States (Donald Pleasence) crashes his plane into the prison area, condemned criminal and one time war hero Snake Plissken (played with laconic glee by Kurt Russell), is sent in to rescue him from the highly dangerous fortress. Carpenter’s cult hit is a subversive and satirical take on a New York which was at the time (it was made in 1982), riddled with crime and corruption. The film also takes swipes at right wing paranoia by offering an alarming vision of how the average American would really like to solve escalating crime. Cast includes Isaac Hayes, Harry Dean Stanton, Ernest Borgnine, Lee Van Cleef and Adrienne Barbeau.
